newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- Fed watch continues.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- Fed watch continues.

text.p: U.S. municipal bonds marked time Tuesday as players waited to see whether Federal Reserve policy makers would raise short-term interest rates.
One trader said while he sold some bonds at slightly better levels than where they came a few days ago, the Fed watch was stifling action.

"Anything that has taken place is against an order, and it's mostly wirehouses buying just so they have inventory for the retail (customer)," the trader said. "There is very little Street playing going on at all."

While some players expected today's Federal Open Market Committee meeting to yield a 25 basis point hike in short-term rates, just as many expect no change, market players said. An announcement is expected at 1415 EDT.

"I just think that there is more downside potential than upside," one trader said. If they don't change, maybe that's built into the market, and they sell it. If they bump it, it's just going to give a reason to sell."
The trader said the potential for a 7.0 percent long U.S. Treasury bond appears much more likely than the potential for a 6.75 percent bond.
"And I think that seems to be the feeling throughout most of the street right now," he said.

In the government market, the benchmark 30-year bond was down 5/32 at 96-4/32 to yield 6.93 percent. In debt futures, the June municipal contract was down 3/32 at 116-14/32. The June T-bond contract was down 9/32 at 109-20/32. The MOB spread was 218 ticks.
Tuesday's actively quoted municipal issues included Oregon State Department of Administrative Services 5.8 percent certificates were bid at 99-3/4, down from Monday's closing dollar price of 100.
Turning to new issues, Nevada is expected to sell $285 million of general obligation bonds via competitive bidding at 1030 EDT on Tuesday.
On the negotiated side, New York City is expected to sell about $740 million of GOs Wednesday via Lehman Brothers.
The City on Monday sold $63 million of bonds to retail investors during the second day of a presale order period, bringing the total so far to $133 million.
